title: Will the book “Superforecasting" (2015) be on the New York Times Bestseller's list by the end of October?
preds: Whooo hoo! I'm mad that I went from 95 - 75 on Oct. 6, but such as life.
if it got this far by the 9th, momentum is favorable to be in the top 10 in 22 more days(10/31)
if it got this far by the 9th, momentum is favorable to be in the top 10 in 22 more days(10/31)
Revised based on NYT listing of sales activity.  Guess a lot of forecasters bought it.  It is very enlightening.

It's a 15-, not 10-book list.  We shouldn't just ask whether Aziz will fall, though, but also what's the sales of 1944, the book just below Superforecasting -- and relative extent to which it's willing to game the system with bulk orders and such. Simon & Schuster have a book on the list, Crown doesn't.

Following Gjdrew. Even if the scorers discard the Nov. 1 list on the basis of a technicality, there is a chance for the Oct. 25 list to make it.

1-3 odds. It's the type of book that makes the list, but it's a very short timespan for it to rise. It's a bought-not-read book, and the genre is crowded (too many "The Signal and the Noise"-type books) without being in actual high-demand.
Moving up 2% from 8% because of the good review in the Economist.  But I still think there's a lot of "since I am interested in this, then most others will be too" bias.
and thanks to @000 and @GJDrew, back up we go
Gjdrew has me worried,  moving up so i am not completely wrong.
Convinced by the comments by GJDrew, 000, and others, I'm shifting slightly positive.

I take it back.  Those NYT lists are weekly, and we don't have to worry about tail off.   Last week, Superforecasting did quite well (22-51), better than Aziz Ansari (#10) did a week before that, and almost reaching Plunder and Deceit level (#7).  I'm projecting Superforecasting to come at #9 now on the next list.

The current bottom of the Non-Fiction Hardcover list is My Fight/Your Fight. [1]  This is #454 in Amazon Books.    Tetlock's book is #183 in Amazon Books.  So I give it a shot, it's simple math.  If there is a correlation of 1 between positions on Non-Fiction hardcover and Amazon Books rank, our guy's book should end up in the top 5 or so.

Looking at Warren Hatch's Sept. 1 forecast, he makes the point that the last release of a new NY Times bestseller list before the end of the month would be Oct. 25. The actual wording of the question appears to be whether it will "Be on...list by the end of October," rather than have sold enough copies by the end of October to be reported on the list to be released Nov. 1. So if the scorers follow the exact wording, they will say, oops, too bad, you were a few minutes late...
The book seems potentially of interest to a wide swath of the public. But end of Oct. coming soon.
Reading the book now.    Good but technical discussion may be less attractive for some readers (but yes, important content.)
People love stats more and more.
People love stats more and more.
Most likely not, only enlightened people like this stuff as we all know most Americans are brain dead.
Good media coverage but too many more interesting (to the general public) titles are out in general non-fiction.
End of October will be here soon.  The book and Dr. Tetlock seem to continue to get good media coverage.

Regarding Delorean's well researched analysis, given the "clarification-free" problems on this site, I can see his concerns. However, a power player analysis suggests that the scorers should be motivated to judge this question on the basis of the actual facts of October sales rather than having a secret agenda of only counting earlier sales.

Revising downward after looking harder at the NYT list publishing cycle and this question's closing date. I think there's a very good chance that Superforecasting will appear on the monthly "Business" list, but that list reflects the prior month (the Oct list "reflects sales in September"), etc. I don't think that the list will be published in time to fulfill the question.
Not widely known or broadly interesting. Also October is fast passing by
slight adjustment up based on recent press and dominich's analysis, but still skeptical.

Given compilation dates, Superforecasting (currently ranked #1 Best Seller in Business & Forecasting by the US Amazon site) could appear here in the chart published online  next week (and in 18 Oct print edition of NYT reflecting sales for week ending 3rd Oct)	= see note at bottom of http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-11/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html

It is not readers of the NYT (or for that matter The Economist, which just ran a favourable review) who determine what's a best-seller.  Placement on the Times' list is not an award for being a good book, it's pretty straightforward reporting on actual sales.

Going down on my prediction. This was probably a mistake to forecast.  I know little about the attributes of NYT Best Sellers. Now I must study.
And perhaps I'm right, but I'll just sit here for a day or so, first.

Reaffirming my previous forecast that it is improbable that this question will resolve positively, and becoming more seriously pessimistic regarding its chances. As an aside, my copy is waiting at home, and Amazon emailed me to let me know that the price had fallen by $1.43. Law of supply and demand I suppose....
Pulling back closer to my original forecast after it slipped at Amazon (#118 today). The best seems over. Will change again if there's a flicker.

I was hoping to see a review by David Brooks and see it zoom up.  There's many positive blurbs out about it and it is doing well, but doesn't seem to be doing spectacularly.  So, I'm going to moderate my forecast.

I'm increasing my odds a bit based on recent news.  There is an interesting correlation problem for this question; the success of the GJOpen Tournament and of this book are presumably related.  Thus, your forecast matters more if Superforecasting is on the NYT Bestsellers List then if it isn't.  This should lead to general overestimation.

Bumping up from 88% to 96%. Have a hunch that it might debut on NYT bestseller list.
Reaffirming my previous forecast and hedging down slightly. Greatest concern is the ability with such a short timeframe to generate the velocity of sales needed to get to the best seller's list.

It got a very good review on "Seeking Alpha", and the current rank on Amazon is 32.
It got a very good review on "Seeking Alpha", and the current rank on Amazon is 32.

Moving up slightly as some of the high forecasts are making me wobble, even though I remain convinced it will not break in.  My basis remains that I think the book will be categorised as a business book and as such it will have to feature in the non fiction category (these need thousands in a week, not the hundreds to get onto Amazons list); that said,  I could be toast if they put it in the Advice, How to & Miscellany category.  I don't see it getting into the monthly categories for business in the timeframe, as the question requires it to be on a list in October and the October monthly sales are only published in November.    It is not able to get into the best sellers list until 18th October as the results are backward looking by two weeks.   For that week (18th), it has not sold the full week, it has taken from 29th - 3rd, but it is its opening salvo (but even on amazon overall it is not getting out of the 20's and their bar is very low).  On balance, and on the basis it will be in non fiction, saying it wont likely make it.  Then 4-10th Sept is next big shot.  Will modify upwards if the Amazon rankings skyrocket between now and then.

Historically, it's a fantastic time to launch a book, as it's before the holidays, and there's a bit of a lull in the industry.  The book's been making headway on blogs (Economist, Seeking Alpha) and is #1 across multiple Amazon categories (which doesn't factor into the NYT list, but is still a good indicator).  Non-fiction is traditionally the largest and most profitable market aside from children's, and Tetlock's got the rep, the social proof and the track record to back it up.
The WSJ bump will be significant.
Moving up a bit more since it's already #20 on Amazon's book list, and #5 on Amazon's business book list.  Publicity moves very fast... I under-estimated the speed of change once a campaign starts.
Moving up a bit more since it's already #20 on Amazon's book list, and #5 on Amazon's business book list.  Publicity moves very fast... I under-estimated the speed of change once a campaign starts.

Seems like a reasonable expectation. Superforecasting appears to be receiving more hype than any other nonfiction work at the moment. 1 month is more than enough time to make the charts.
Seems totally doable.  WHY NOT ME?, by Mindy Kaling is at 11 in Amazon's "Books", and was number 1 in NYT Nonfiction list.
Listed on Amazon as #1Best Seller in Technology and not released until September 29th.   Lots of publicity on Amazon.   Hope our politicians buy it.

Going to move up a little bit on @praedico comment.  The time frame is a bit short (1 month), but world moves very fast these days.  I may have under-estimated the speed of social feedback/measurement.  It's the Feiler Faster Thesis.

I have access to a program that receives advance copies for review, and this book went out of stock quickly. Pre-release sales on Amazon are strong. A nonfiction book doesn't have to sell nearly as many copies as a fiction book to make the NYTimes Bestsellers list. "Superforecasting" is published by a major publisher, so it should be in many stores that the NYTimes tracks (I realize that they track advance sales, not retail sales). On the other hand, the bar to entry for bestseller lists is higher during the pre-holiday shopping season. But I see no reason this book shouldn't reach it.
WSJ article will ramp up sales.
Raising forecast, since it is Amazon #22 in books right now
That's quite a jump in rankings on Amazon since I last made my forecast. Not quite sure how an Amazon ranking translates to being on the NYT bestseller's list though.
That's quite a jump in rankings on Amazon since I last made my forecast. Not quite sure how an Amazon ranking translates to being on the NYT bestseller's list though.

Sorry, this forecast is pulled completely out of my hat. No citations. Just apologies.
Keeping in mind:
1.	this is an accessible book, written in layman’s terms, co-written by a journalist (good writer) that can be understood without expert knowledge in Tetlock’s field
2.	it is a kind of self-improvement, skill development book about a topic that applies to so many people’s fields and interests, it appeals to a wide variety of people
3.	AND it is coming out in Christmas shopping season
4.	There are several other books on Amazon about forecasting, there is interest in this topic.
5.	A book needs to sell about 4000 copies in one week to get on the NYT best selling booklist. (caveat-completely unsubstantiated statistic, found on an author’s blog)
6.	I have read numbers between 3000 and 10000 participants in GJP. Human curiosity being what it is, many of them will want to buy a copy. Just to see what Mr. Tetlock says about the project they were involved with. Especially those of us now participating in GJ Inc.  Wannabe superforecasters like me want to glean helpful info. If half of GJP participants go buy the book when it first comes out, there is a good possibility one week could see over 4000 copies bought, between participants and general public.
7.	Media articles about forecasting and GJP have put forecasting on the public’s radar. (Even I heard about it by 2014, and my teenagers will tell you I am the least likely, uncoolest person to know anything that’s trendy.)

I am really not sure WHAT best seller list this question references.  There is a business list subclass.  I think it will do better in that class, as well as behavioural sciences, and less stellar of a performance in non-fiction/general.
It's released Sept 29
It's in the business/management class- adjusting my rate up some as while a lot of good non-fiction is coming out, not as many good business titles
People might be looking for some way to predict economic markets esp in Oct.  Many will think the book might give them insight, so I expect a spike then a drop as more reviews come out.
BUT, still not a lot of movement on social media about the book other than a couple of committed spammers.
Non fiction list most likely to contain fluffy books related to election candidates (heavy sales supported by fans)
Too soon in October unless  promotion/adverting hits something really big
Considering that those who praised some aspect of the project in the past (FT, nyt, etc) are "thought leaders" and perhaps a rising concern with geopolitical variability, I am somewhat optimistic

The timing seems too short from publishing date to gain sufficient market momentum against other titles.  Some interviews, published articles, excellent reviews of the book could increase the chance of making the bottom of the list.
I had forgotten about the Science category. Thanks InVinoVeritas.

- The book would do well in the category 'Science', since these books tend not to be popular.
- The author has no appeal, but the subject has. Title of book is short and appealling.
- I wonder what the promotion-effort will be, but there are lots of possibilities, so this is likely to be a success.

i think people underestimate how easy it is to get on NYtimes best seller list (not taking anything away from those authors who do, or disparaging those who dont - just all about media hype which this has/will have)

I would say no but there are so many categories that it could pop up in that it may just make it.  There will be an interest from previous forecasters and I can see NPR doing a segment on it..so maybe..but end of October is a short timeframe..
The overall interest in forecasting probably is not large enough.
As the world becomes more complex and less rational, books on forecasting will become more popular.

The Vine reviewers that I know and respect the most have not thought all that much of it.  There weren't many copies offered that I could discern, and my attempts to get one from the publisher- as a top US reviewer, went into the void.  So I am not so sure how aggressive the marketing is on this book with top influencers in the Amazon market or how well targeted those galley copies that did go out were.  I could not find the book on sites that typically provide ARCs to me either.  Books that are very successful typically are easily available to reviewers and known market influencers.
Also, there are some phenomenal non-fiction titles coming out in September and November, so it will have a LOT of competition.  I think Black Flags:Rise of ISIS will be way up there.  Superforecasting though, I'm not sure.  If I had been able to get a copy, I could predict this a lot better.  It concerns me that the people I've talked to had reservations about the book.    I'm giving it a 38% chance though, because I think it will have some following in the IC and with forecasters.  It IS a hot topic.  I can't see it being near the top if it is though.  I've not seen this many GOOD non-fiction titles being released in such a short time in years.

The Vine reviewers that I know and respect the most have not thought all that much of it.  There weren't many copies offered that I could discern, and my attempts to get one from the publisher- as a top US reviewer, went into the void.  So I am not so sure how aggressive the marketing is on this book with top influencers in the Amazon market or how well targeted those galley copies that did go out were.  I could not find the book on sites that typically provide ARCs to me either.  Books that are very successful typically are easily available to reviewers and known market influencers.

Last I saw the book was at the top of the list in it's category on Amazon.com. I think Amazon, because it is SO widely used, is a decent starting point from which to make judgments about popularity among consumers.
Adding to that--if a book is top on an Amazon list, that probably speaks not only to the content but to the PR team behind "selling" the idea of the book to others. If they've managed to "sell" it to Amazon that is a great start & it's visibility and the awareness consumers have of it will only increase. 
 So based off that, I think that Superforecasting has a pretty decent shot of at least making it on to the NYT list in any category by the end of October.

The time to become listed on the New York Times bestseller's list is rather short. Marketing is not sufficient here - an sufficient demand of the topic has to exist, which does not appear to be massive yet. Though the book will likely be amazing (judging from early reviews and material present on Master class series on edge.org), significant efforts would be needed to expand books interest among masses. On the other hand, targeting major 'overlapping' audience like Tim Ferriss' podcast listeners could flip the coin significantly.

These bestseller lists are not based on attainment of any arbitrary number of sales; they're relative, so a whole lot depends on the competition--on what other books have recently come out.  I've jokingly been saying, "For example, if Trump's biography comes out the same week as your book, you're toast."  Well, guess what:  Trump's book "In Pursuit of Success" will come out the week before "Superforecasting".  I don't see an upside to this for "Superforecasting".  Just as Trump the Candidate has sucked up all the air in the Republican party presidential campaign, Trump the Writer will suck up all the airtime for book reviews.

What does it take to get on the NYT bestseller list?  Here's what I've learned:
-not every book bought counts.  NYT counts only some sellers' sales.  Grocery stores probably don't count, but independent booksellers' sales get extra weight. Airport sales may not count.
-a sales peak during one week is all that's needed because the counts are weekly.  Every week is a new race.
-if the book physically ships out of the book seller’s warehouse weeks before the pub date, it goes from “pre-order” status to “sold” — and thus, it does not get counted in launch week
-bulk orders are weighted differently.  If this book is used as a textbook, not every sale will count
-500-1,000 sales are needed to hit Amazon's list, and the NYT list is assumed to require 10x that:  5-9k
-there's seasonal variations, so the bar raises & lowers.  January is a slow month for sales; Sept is a high one
-a ton depends on what other books were released at the same time/what the competition is.  I've been unable to figure out what other books in its category will be released in Sept.
-the bar is lower/higher in different NYT list categories

The best comparison for "Superforecasting" is probably "The Signal and the Noise" by Nate Silver.  "The Signal and the Noise" was published on September 27, 2012, and made it to the NYT bestseller list on October 28th.  That suggests an average time of a month to make the list, or a 50% chance of making the list before the end of October (since "Superforecasting" will be released on September 29th).  However, I don't think that "Superforecasting" will be quite as popular or successful as "The Signal and the Noise" (which seems to be the strongest book in its category, and thus hardly a typical case).  I give it a 25% chance of being that successful, for a 12% chance of being on the bestseller list by the end of October.

The best comparison for "Superforecasting" is probably "The Signal and the Noise" by Nate Silver.  "The Signal and the Noise" was published on September 27, 2012, and made it to the NYT bestseller list on October 28th.  That suggests an average time of a month to make the list, or a 50% chance of making the list before the end of October (since "Superforecasting" will be released on September 29th).  However, I don't think that "Superforecasting" will be quite as popular or successful as "The Signal and the Noise" (which seems to be the strongest book in its category, and thus hardly a typical case).  I give it a 25% chance of being that successful, for a 12% chance of being on the bestseller list by the end of October.
From what I understand the book only needs to be at the top of it's category.  It doesn't directly compete with the latest fiction novel.
From what I understand the book only needs to be at the top of it's category.  It doesn't directly compete with the latest fiction novel.
While it may generate sales as a business book over time, don't think it will make an immediate splash.   Looking forward to reading it though!
In reading through some of the comments, I think my initial prediction of 39% was still too optimistic. Revising down.
Too narrow a topic; too narrow a timeframe. "Bought with" books on Amazon are lucky to get above 4000. Pre-ordered mine with the GJP stipend.

Gaming bestseller lists is an industry unto itself (http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2013/02/22/heres-how-you-buy-your-way-onto-the-new-york-times-bestsellers-list/).
I would love to see it happen, but intuition says "not a wide enough audience".  Let's have a show of hands amongst all of us, the early beta-testers of GJP II.  How many are going to buy?

I would love to see it happen, but intuition says "not a wide enough audience".  Let's have a show of hands amongst all of us, the early beta-testers of GJP II.  How many are going to buy?

It seems common for authors of this kind of niche book to get on various main-stream media (TV)/syndicated media (Radio) outlets BEFORE the official release of the book.  I have not seen/heard the good professor on any segments as of yet.  Getting on at least one major mass audience outlet seems like a prerequisite for getting on "The List".

Base case: I checked latest NYT 15 non-fiction books. One (Jimmy Carter's) had 59 reviews on Amazon; the next lowest was about 150 reviews; it went all the way up to a few thousand. In contrast, Tetlock's "Expert Political Judgement" has only 34 reviews since 2006. I can;t see why the new book would do spectacularly better.
GJP audience: I don't see a huge audience among the GJP participants. If 20,000 took part in GJP, about half hardly participated (based on my 10-person group sample). Of the others, I doubt more than 15% will actually buy the book. And, many of those are probably the type who will put it on their list and get to it, as part of their reading.
Finally, the subject-matter is a step removed from being personally actionable. The idea that crowds have wisdom is interesting, but it is not enough motivation for most readers to invest the time in knowing more than a high-level summary.

I understand it takes about 10,000 sales within a week for a book to get on the NYT Bestseller list. The GJP and Tetlock have been getting media coverage over the last few years and are probably well known by now among people interested in the subject. However, my simplistic approach is to say that there were 20,000 participants in GJP's Season 4, and a large proportion of them are going to buy the book, many may have pre-ordered it already. I think there's a strong likelihood that the book will show up on the Best Seller List in the first week after release.

Joining at the high end at 66%. Apparently, the list is updated every Sunday, so last available date this year is 25 October ... presumably they do the final tally a day or two earlier, maybe Friday at the end of the business week, which is 23 October. Just over 3 weeks to surge in the ranks. I think it happens.

I just went with 99 percent on this one.  This might be a rookie mistake, not being used to non-market-based platform.  But my rationale is based on the thought that Dr. Tetlock's other book for a popular audience, on expert judgement, was a best seller; he's gotten ample positive press on his ground-breaking research since then; and since this question really concerns how strong early buzz on the book would be vs. it's objective quality, I'd say it will get a lot, lot of positive word-of-mouth from the 1,000s of folks who've volunteered for the Good Judgment Project before now--many of whom are liable to be influential in getting others to read, and at least some of whom (me) post a lot about this stuff to Facebook, where people can read about it and get interested.  I might be over-confident about my hit-picking skills for non-fiction, but I did post the Economist's article on Picketty's Capital in the 21st Century to Facebook when they reviewed it in French, and said how eager I was to read the English translation.

Malcolm Gladwell has several books on the NYTB currently, including Outliers ~7 years after it was released. I anticipate that Superforecasters could fit into the Gladwell/Silver niche for popular social science with obvious real world applications. I'm hedging because I'm not sure that there's all that much mainstream interest in this -- e.g. there have been 1,700 NYT articles that have mentioned "Malcolm Gladwell," compared to 0 that have mentioned "superforecasting," 3 with "Good Judgment Project" (only 1 since 2012), and 53 that have mentioned "Tetlock."
Four weeks to get on the list. Will revisit forecast after the first week to see how the buzz is.
people are interested in the subject. A short time frame to be #1 but with publicity it could do it

It's a significant book, and it's the type book that appeals to a segment of Times Readers.  The time frame is short, but the book is getting, and will get a lot of buzz. The conclusions are novel enough to attract readers, and many people are interested in forecasting.
I don't think that's enough time to make it.
Given the attention it's already getting and the publisher's influence that's putting it out, it's pretty safe to assume it will do quite well.
The advance buzz is great, and the book is already on the Financial Times long list for Best Business Book of 2015.
May not be as interesting to people outside of a too narrow group. I don't think the genre is out of steam yet, but the bar for writing quality is pretty high. The edit could make this.
Assuming separate lists for fiction and non-fiction.  Interest can peak quickly with good publicity.
